awd_titl_txt: Towards Dynamical Control over Gas-Surface Reactivity: Light Alkane and Carbon Dioxide Activation at Catalytic Metal Surfares
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Ian Harrison of the University of Virginia is using sophisticated laser and molecular beam techniques, coupled with theoretical modeling, to study the reactions of natural gas molecules and carbon dioxide with metal surfaces.   For example, one reaction of interest is that between carbon dioxide (CO2) and hydrogen atoms (H), which can be accelerated when CO2 and H first adsorb on a copper surface (in other words, the metal surface is acting as a catalyst).  Prof. Harrison's research aims to reveal how the initial structures formed when molecules and/or atoms collide with a metal surface determine the products of the reaction and the rates of the reaction.  Understanding the details of molecule-surface reactions may aid the design of next generation catalysts and catalytic processes.  In this way, the research may help advance catalytic technologies to more efficiently make products from natural gas, transformations that currently consume approximately 2% of global energy, and to use carbon dioxide as a chemical feedstock in ways that would reduce net greenhouse gas emissions. Further broader impacts of this research stem from the training of graduate and undergraduate students in the design and construction of advanced experimental instrumentation and complex computer modeling. Outreach activities include giving lessons and lab demonstrations at local elementary and middle schools and providing expanded research opportunities to minority and Federal Work Study undergraduate students. 

The dynamics of activated chemisorption are probed using a heated effusive molecular beam impinging on a single crystal metal surface to measure dissociative/associative sticking probabilities, S(Tg, Ts; angle), as functions of gas & surface temperatures and angle of incidence. New measurements of product state distributions from pulsed laser assisted thermal associative/dissociative desorption (LAAD/LADD) reactions at surfaces will address activated chemisorption beginning from the surface side of the reaction barrier. Interpreted through the principle of detailed balance, the LAAD/LADD measurements define translational energy- resolved thermal sticking probabilities S(Et, T; angle), directly relevant to thermally-driven industrial catalysis. The laser methods provide unique new opportunities to characterize extremely low activated sticking probabilities and to even discriminate between chemically- specific reaction pathways such as C-C or C-H bond cleavage in ethane dissociative chemisorption. The experimental measurements, coupled with dynamically-biased microcanonical theoretical modeling, are being used to test and quantify the control of dynamics over catalytic reactivity, and to relate this dynamical control to specific transition state properties.

por.por_cntn:
Catalysis at metal surfaces is essential to selectively and energy efficiently transform abundant small molecules, like nitrogen, water, carbon dioxide, and light alkanes (natural gas), into the fuels, alcohols, fertilizer, plastics, and commodity chemicals that modern society relies upon. However, the gas-surface reactivity of such small molecules with relatively few degrees of freedom is oftentimes influenced by dynamics that can alter reactivity by orders of magnitude away from the expectations of traditional transition state theory. This project coupled effusive molecular beam and laser experiments with theoretical modeling to learn more about how the geometry of the transition state (i.e., the high energy intermediate species between reactants and products) dictates dynamical biases and modulates reaction rates in gas-surface reactivity. Such dynamical considerations may offer a useful additional control element in the design and optimization of next-generation green catalysts and catalytic pathways.

An effusive molecular beam survey of the thermal equilibrium and non-equilibrium reactivity of linear and branched C1-C9 alkanes on the Pt(111) surface was completed. A linear scaling relation between the activation energy for thermal dissociative chemisorption via C-H bond cleavage and the molecular desorption energy was found. The alkane molecular desorption energies derive from van der Waals interactions and not covalent bonding with the surface. Assuming the molecular desorption energy serves as an experimental measure of the van der Waals stabilization of the initial products of dissociative chemisorption [RH(g)→R(c) + H(c)], a linear [Bronsted-Evans-Polanyi] relationship between the reaction activation energy and the reaction exothermicity was observed which was consistent with a simple model for the alkyl-Pt bond energies. The increase of reactivity with alkane size was overwhelming dominated by the increase in the van der Waals attraction to the surface. The transition state for C-H bond cleavage could be characterized as early and exceptionally loose or entropically unconstrained. Only for the branched tetramethylbutane (TMB) C8 alkane was there evidence for initial C-C bond cleavage in addition to C-H bond cleavage. The relatively weak C-C bond between quaternary C atoms in TMB makes C-C bond cleavage more thermodynamically favorable than C-H bond scission for this alkane, uniquely amongst the alkanes studied.

The reactivity of methane (natural gas) at a Rh(111) surface was examined because this is a favorable system to produce syngas from methane in small scale reactors via catalytic partial oxidation. Our experiments and theoretical analysis showed that molecular vibrational energy was only 55% as effective as translational energy directed along the surface normal in promoting C-H bond cleavage. This dynamical bias is consistent with an early transition state, but one later than that for methane reacting on Pt(111), which is in accord with electronic structure theory calculations. Remarkably, the methane reactivity on the Rh(111) surface at temperatures less than about 700 K was dominated by step defect sites that were present at the level of 0.17% as compared to the perfect terrace sites. On other surfaces, such as Pt(111), product retention at such defect sites would have rendered the defects promptly inactive. By microcanonical modeling of the reactivity of step sites on Rh(111), it was possible to calculate the thermal reactivity of methane observed on defect rich evaporated Rh foils and replicate their elevated kinetic isotope effect (~12) near 300 K which demonstrated the model?s ability to successfully treat quantum mechanical tunneling through the reaction barrier.

The experimental reactivity of HCl on Au(111) reported by the Wodtke lab was modeled using our dynamically-biased precursor mediated microcanonical trapping model of gas-surface reactivity because of our interest in connecting experimental reactivity to transition state properties. Our analysis found that translational energy directed along the surface normal was 38% less effective than vibrational energy in promoting reactivity (indicative of a very late transition state) and that surface phonons, rather than electron-hole pair excitations, were important dissipative elements for this reactive system.

A pulsed laser assisted thermal reactivity technique that is complementary to effusive molecular beam methods for studying gas-surface reactivity was set up using a Nd:YAG laser with pulses of 10 ns duration and initial experiments began.

The project supported a diverse group of 7 graduate and 3 undergraduate students engaged in interdisciplinary training and research in surface science and reaction dynamics relevant to catalysis and sustainability. Half of the students were women and 4 were persons of color. Two of the undergraduates were economically disadvantaged students participating in Federal Work Study. The research group has been active in outreach activities and its graduate students have held executive positions in the L.E.A.D. (Learning through Experiments, Awareness, & Demonstrations) program that promotes chemistry through science education and awareness for K-8 students in the metropolitan Charlottesville area, and throughout the surrounding counties. Over the project period, the project's NSF-funded students have engaged with over 750 students across more than 40 public and private schools across the Commonwealth of Virginia.
